abstract.p: Letter from Marsha Johnson Evans (Girl Scouts USA) replies to Steffen N Johnson's June 30 Op-Ed article on why Boy Scouts had to assert their constitutional right to bar gays

block.p: Re ''A Case the Scouts Had to Win,'' by Steffen N. Johnson (Op-Ed, June 30), about the Supreme Court's ruling that the Boy Scouts have a constitutional right to exclude gay members:
Re ''A Case the Scouts Had to Win,'' by Steffen N. Johnson (Op-Ed, June 30), about the Supreme Court's ruling that the Boy Scouts have a constitutional right to exclude gay members:
Mr. Johnson writes, ''If the Boy Scouts were required to admit leaders who advocated a position contrary to its own, then men could assert the right to lead the Girl Scouts.''
In fact, men can and do serve as co-leaders of Girl Scout troops or groups. Every volunteer and staff position in Girl Scouting is open to men as well as to women.
Girl Scout membership is open to all girls between the ages of 5 and 17, and to men and women over 18 who accept the Girl Scout law and make the Girl Scout promise.
MARSHA JOHNSON EVANS National Executive Director Girl Scouts of the U.S.A. New York, June 30, 2000
